It knows where I live: the code.

NB for complete beginners:
  • Install R – follow the ‘Getting Started’ instructions.
  • Install RStudio, an excellent, free interactive environment for R.
  • In RStudio, install the packages you need to run the scripts below, by copying and pasting the following:
1 install.packages(“ggmap”)
2 install.packages(“ggplot2″)
3 install.packages(“jsonlite”)
4 install.packages(“plyr”)
And on to the good stuff…

1) Download the .json location data from Google Takeout.

2) Import the data into R, get it into a useful format, and plot it. I haven’t included the code for the animated gif, as it gets a bit more involved (and to be perfectly honest, my code get’s all messy and horrible because I got tired :P). In short: make a function to prude a series of images, then stitch them all into a .gif using ImageMagick (not in R). If you’re interested, just ask.

 1 # Load in the raw data from the JSON file ----------------------------------------------------
 2 require(jsonlite)
 3 require(plyr)
 4 
 5 raw = fromJSON('/Path/To/LocationHistory.json')
 6 
 7 # Get the 'locations' part of the list
 8 locs = raw$locations
 9 
10 # these are all the columns that it contains...
11 names(locs)
12 # they're in various formats...
13 lapply(locs,class)
14 
15 # Get columns into useful formats -----------------------------------------
16 
17 ldf = data.frame(t=rep(0,nrow(locs)))
18 
19 # time is in POSIX * 1000 (milliseconds) format, convert it to useful scale...
20 ldf$t = as.numeric(locs$timestampMs)/1000
21 class(ldf$t) = 'POSIXct'
22 
23 # lat/lon are xE7, convert them to usable numbers...
24 ldf$lat = as.numeric(locs$latitudeE7/1E7)
25 ldf$lon = as.numeric(locs$longitudeE7/1E7)
26 
27 # Accuracy doesn't need changing.
28 ldf$accuracy = locs$accuracy
29 
30 # Activity guesses (it can tell when you're on a bike?!) are in a list... we can unpack these lists to get the most likely activity for each location (takes a while, depending on the size of your dataset).
31 
32 # get the most likely activity type and confidence for each time point.
33 act = laply(locs$activitys, function(f) {
34  if(is.null(f[[1]])) data.frame(activity=NA,confidence=NA,stringsAsFactors=F) else data.frame(activity=f[[2]][[1]][[1]][1],confidence=f[[2]][[1]][[2]][1],stringsAsFactors=F)
35 },.progress="text")
36 
37 # combine activity data with the main dataset
38 ldf$activity = as.character(act[,1])
39 ldf$confidence = as.numeric(act[,2])
40 
41 # Velocity, altitude and heading need no alteration:
42 ldf$velocity = locs$velocity
43 ldf$altitude = locs$altitude
44 ldf$heading = locs$heading
45 
46 # We now have a data.frame 'ldf', which contains all the location data google has on us!
47 
48 # And plot it... ----------------------------------------
49 
50 require(ggplot2)
51 require(ggmap)
52 
53 EU = get_map(c(0,48),5,source='google')
54 
55 ggmap(EU) + geom_point(data=ldf,aes(lon,lat),colour='red')
56 
57 # Let's just look at the UK stuff...
58 
59 # first, define a quick funciton to clip the data to the current map
60 mapclip = function(df,map) {
61  coord = attr(map,'bb')
62  return(subset(df,lon>coord$ll.lon & lon<coord$ur.lon & lat>coord$ll.lat & lat<coord$ur.lat))
63 }
64 
65 UK = get_map('Oxford, UK',7,scale=2)
66 ldf.uk = mapclip(ldf,UK)
67 
68 ggmap(UK) + geom_point(data=ldf.uk,aes(x=lon,y=lat),colour='red',size=2)
69 
70 # Let's have a look at Cambridge...
71 
72 cam = get_map('Cambridge, UK',13,scale=4)
73 clip = coord_map(projection='mercator',xlim=c(0.1,0.15),ylim=c(52.19,52.23))
74 ldf.cam = mapclip(ldf,cam)
75 ggmap(cam) + geom_point(data=ldf.cam,aes(x=lon,y=lat),colour='red',size=1,alpha=0.5) + clip
76 
77 # And what do I do in cambridge?
78 ldf.cam.act = subset(ldf.cam,activity %in% c("inVehicle","onBicycle","onFoot","still"))
79 ggmap(cam) + geom_point(data=ldf.cam.act,aes(x=lon,y=lat,colour=activity),size=2) + scale_colour_manual(values=c('red','orange','yellow','black')) + clip
80 
81 # A little closer? And add in the non-active markers, to get more of a trend.
82 camclose = get_map('Cambridge, UK',15,scale=4)
83 ldf.cam.act.close = mapclip(ldf.cam.act,camclose)
84 ldf.cam.close = mapclip(ldf,camclose)
85 ggmap(camclose) + geom_point(data=ldf.cam.close,aes(lon,lat),colour='purple',alpha=0.6) + geom_point(data=ldf.cam.act.close,aes(x=lon,y=lat,colour=activity),size=2) + scale_colour_manual(values=c('red','orange','yellow','black'))
